Imagine having a virtual assistant that works alongside you as you browse the web, helping you make sense of cluttered pages overloaded with information. That’s the promise of Microsoft’s Copilot Vision, which is now available in preview.

Copilot Vision isn’t just another AI assistant you ask questions. It’s like having a second pair of eyes that can scan, analyze, and offer insights on the information in front of you. Whether you’re comparing products or digging through complex reports, Copilot Vision could make overwhelming tasks much easier.

It could be a valuable tool for business owners, helping you to make decisions faster and achieve a more efficient workflow. Need to find the best supplier, analyze market trends, or get online research done quickly? Copilot Vision works in real time to help you focus on what’s important to you.

For now, it only works on specific websites in Microsoft Edge and is only available to Copilot Pro subscribers. As for privacy, Microsoft's said all data is deleted after use.

Does this sound like the kind of smart assistant that could help your team work faster, or are you still on the fence about using AI in your business?
postsData.commentAdded: Excited to see how Copilot Vision can transform productivity! A game-changer for navigating complex information and enhancing decision-making.

Lessons in Style, Humor, and Resilience: A Deep Dive into Sakamoto desu ga? 

As anime continues to evolve as a storytelling medium, few shows have managed to blend humor, style, and life lessons quite like Sakamoto desu ga? (also known as Haven’t You Heard? I’m Sakamoto). For anyone who’s a fan of witty character development and comedic brilliance, this show is a gem that not only entertains but also provides valuable insights into navigating life’s challenges with grace.

Here are a few takeaways from the unforgettable protagonist, Sakamoto, that resonate beyond the screen:

Confidence is Key: Sakamoto's unwavering self-assurance teaches us that embracing who we are, no matter how unconventional, is powerful. His ability to stay calm and collected in any situation is a true example of maintaining confidence under pressure.

Embrace Your Uniqueness: Sakamoto’s style—whether in his impeccable fashion or his quirky actions—reminds us to embrace what makes us stand out. It's a lesson in authenticity and leadership.

The Power of Humor: The series brilliantly combines slapstick humor and subtle wit. It reminds us that laughter, even in the most unlikely situations, can break down barriers and connect people in meaningful ways.

Resilience in the Face of Adversity: No matter how many challenges Sakamoto faces, he handles each one with composure, making it clear that resilience and adaptability are traits we should all nurture.

Whether you’re looking for a good laugh or an insightful reminder of how to approach life with style, Sakamoto desu ga? is a must-watch. It's more than just an anime—it's a masterclass in cool, with a sprinkle of inspiration that can be applied in both personal and professional settings.

What's your favorite moment or lesson from Sakamoto desu ga? Let’s discuss in the comments!

comments.commentText: The way laughter connects people was portrayed so well. Truly an important reminder!

𝗢𝗻𝗲 𝗸𝗲𝘆 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗮𝘄𝗮𝘆?

postsData.name:
Amir Tabch
Amir Tabch
postsData.content:
The day I won the argument… & lost the room

Years ago, I was in a heated discussion with my team. I had facts, figures, & logic on my side. I dissected every counterpoint with surgical precision. By the time I finished, there was silence.

I had won.

Or so I thought.

Then I looked around. Instead of nods of agreement, I saw blank stares. Arms crossed. That "Yeah, but screw this guy" energy was thick in the air.

I had successfully proven my point—but in the process, I had lost my team.

That was the day I learned one of the most dangerous leadership traps: the curse of being right.

Great leadership isn’t about winning arguments—it’s about winning trust, alignment, & commitment. If your goal is to be right all the time, congratulations—you’re an excellent debater. But you might be a terrible leader.

Here’s why:

1. People would rather follow someone they trust than someone who’s always right

A study from HBR found that trust in leadership is the #1 predictor of high-performance teams. Not intelligence. Not charisma. Trust.

& guess what? Trust isn’t built by being the smartest person in the room. It’s built by showing humility, listening, & making people feel heard.

Leaders who obsess over being right often bulldoze over other people’s ideas. The result? Their teams check out. People stop challenging them. Innovation dies.

2. The ‘Rightness Paradox’: The more you prove you’re right, the more people resist

Psychologists call this reactance theory—when people feel their autonomy is threatened, they resist, even if they know you’re right.

Ever argued with someone & noticed that the harder you push, the harder they dig in? That’s reactance in action.

In leadership, it’s worse. If your team feels like every conversation is a battle they’re doomed to lose, they’ll either stop contributing or quietly sabotage your decisions.

3. Being right doesn’t mean you’re making the best decision

Daniel Kahneman, Nobel Prize-winning psychologist, talks about cognitive biases that trick us into believing we’re more rational than we actually are. One of the worst offenders? The overconfidence bias.

Leaders who are too confident in their own correctness miss critical blind spots. They mistake certainty for wisdom & logic for leadership.

Great leaders don’t just ask, “Am I right?” They ask, “What am I missing?”

If leadership was just about having the right answers, Google would be our CEO.

But leadership isn’t about knowing everything—it’s about bringing people along.

So, the next time you’re about to unleash a masterclass in why you’re right, stop & ask: Am I trying to win the argument… or am I trying to win my team?

Because the best leaders don’t just win debates. They win people.

comments.commentText:
If you’ve ever found yourself in a meeting thinking, Why can’t people just admit I’m right?, take a breath. Here’s how to shift from proving points to leading people:

 Listen like you might be wrong. Even if you’re 99% sure you’re right, leave room for the 1% chance you’re not. It makes people more willing to engage.

 Trade ‘winning the argument’ for ‘winning alignment.’ If you force a decision, you’ll get compliance. If you build buy-in, you’ll get commitment.

 Ask, “What do you see that I don’t?” This shifts the conversation from proving who's right to uncovering what’s best for the organization.

 Know when to let go. Sometimes, letting someone else be right—even when you know they’re not—is the best long-term move. People learn by doing, not by being told.

postsData.commentAdded: This is such a powerful reminder! Winning trust is far more valuable than winning arguments. Lets focus on collaboration over correct answers!

postsData.content:
Working Hard Won't Get You Promoted.

7 Uncomfortable Truths About Career Advancement
(And what to do next)

You’ve been there…
Watching someone else present your idea.
Sitting silently, frustration twisting in your gut.

Your silence isn't just killing you inside.
It's costing you opportunities and advancement.

Here's what nobody tells you about getting promoted:
(And how you can take control)

1. You Stay Invisible
↳ Your hard work means nothing if no one notices it
↳ Document your wins and share progress intentionally

2. You Trust Process Over Politics
↳ You believe the system will recognize your effort
↳ Build relationships with decision-makers strategically

3. You Let Others Tell Your Story
↳ You wait for others to notice while they claim credit
↳ Learn to advocate for yourself professionally

4. You Mistake Activity for Achievement
↳ You focus on doing more instead of doing right
↳ Prioritize high-visibility projects and strategic work

5. You Play by Rules Others Write
↳ You follow the path while others create their own
↳ Design your career strategy beyond just working hard

6. You Confuse Loyalty with Growth
↳ You stay too long hoping hard work will be noticed
↳ Set clear milestones for your advancement

7. You Choose Comfort Over Growth
↳ You stay in your lane, afraid to ruffle feathers
↳ Take calculated risks and expand your influence


Hard work opens doors.

But you have to walk through them.

Which bold move are you ready to take next?
Share below

True high performance isn't found in intense bursts of energy.

It's found in consistent effort.

The most successful people aren't those who can push themselves to extreme limits for a short time.

But those who can maintain a steady, purposeful pace.

They understand that true excellence comes from discipline, not dramatic explosions of effort.

Would you rather have an athlete who burns bright and fast, or one who consistently delivers exceptional results?

The answer is clear.

Consistency is the real game-changer.

This means balancing intensity with smart, sustainable practices.

It means understanding your limits.
Respecting your body and mind.
And building a routine that supports long-term growth.

So forget about trying to be a spectacular flash in the pan.

Focus on showing up.

Focus on the small, daily improvements.

Focus on building a practice that you can sustain not just for weeks, but for years.

Because in the end, success isn't about how hard you can work for a moment.

It's about how well you can keep it up, day after day, week after week, year after year.

Slow and steady doesn't just win the race. It dominates it.

Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science & Robotics
Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science & Robotics
postsData.content:
Agentic AI layers form the structural foundation that enables AI systems to operate autonomously, make decisions, and adapt dynamically to changing environments. These layers typically consist of four key components. The Perception Layer gathers and processes data from various sources, such as sensors, text, or images, to build an understanding of the environment. The Cognition Layer analyzes this information, applies reasoning, and formulates decisions or strategies using AI models, including machine learning and logical inference. The Action Layer translates these decisions into executable tasks, allowing the AI to interact with digital or physical systems. Finally, the Feedback Layer monitors outcomes, assesses performance, and refines future actions based on learning from past experiences. Together, these layers enable AI to function as an independent agent, continuously improving its decision-making and adaptability in complex scenarios.

For more follow me at:
postsData.commentAdded: Great breakdown of Agentic AI layers! Exciting to see how these components work together to enhance decision-making and adaptability!

Elizabeth Kershaw
Elizabeth Kershaw
postsData.content:
455 days ago I got turned down for a promotion.

So I promoted myself instead. How? ↴

By booking a one-way ticket to Asia. ️

Okay, I know that sounds a little dramatic, but hear me out 

Just over a year ago I walked into my yearly review with all the receipts as to how I’d far outgrown just the title of “Brand Designer”.

→ I’d helped organise company PR events,
→ I’d developed and run the company socials,
→ I’d designed websites and user experiences,
→ I'd branched out into animation/motion graphics.

I was told that they’d “get back to me”

↳ They never did.

Eventually I got frustrated with how company politics was holding me back from reaching my fullest potential. 

 But I had my own idea:

I wanted to spend a year in Asia, building businesses and experimenting to see if I could create something valuable out of my own passions.

I’d spent a year saving as much money as I could, working evenings and weekends so I could FINALLY create things I was truly passionate about.

(Moving to Asia was going to make my money last waaaaay longer.)

 So I booked a one-way ticket to Vietnam. 🇻🇳

And honestly, it was the best (and scariest) decision I’ve ever made.

 Now I’ve been in SE Asia for almost a year!!! CRAZY!!!

& I’m the Founder of. I'm very lucky that my work and the people I interact with every day light me the F**K UP 

But more importantly, I’ve gained more than just a change of title:

 I alone set the pace on how quickly I progress.
 My earnings are directly related to my input.
 I’m doing work that I’m passionate about.
 There’s no ‘optics’ or politics to uphold.
 I have autonomy over the skills I learn.
 I work for people I genuinely care for.
 I can work when I feel motivated.
 I’m building my OWN wealth.

I realise now that by chasing a promotion, I was prioritising growth in the wrong direction.

Sometimes the biggest risks yield the biggest rewards, and that’s exactly what happened when I booked that ticket a year ago.

I could never have predicted how different my life would be now! 

So just a reminder:

- YOU are in control of your own life
- If you’re not happy with it you have the power to change it
- Your greatest potential is hiding on the other side of the biggest risks

 Where have you taken control of your life recently?

postsData.content:
7 Hidden Performance Killers Sabotaging Your Success:


You're working harder than ever.

But something feels off.

Here are the hidden culprits stealing your success:

1️⃣ The False Urgency Trap
↳ Everything feels important.
↳ Nothing gets your best energy.
↳ Your real priorities suffer in silence.

Solution
↳ Rate tasks 1-3, only 1's get today's energy
↳ schedule deep work before reactive work

2️⃣ Borrowed Standards
↳ You're chasing the success of others.
↳ Your unique advantages go unused.
↳ Your authentic edge stays hidden.

Solution
↳ List your unique strengths, then build from them
↳ Measure success by your growth, not others' goals

3️⃣ The Preparation Paradox
↳ You're too busy executing to prepare.
↳ Quick wins become long-term losses.
↳ Your foundation cracks under pressure.

Solution
↳ Block 2 hours weekly for pure planning time
↳ Create systems today that serve you tomorrow

4️⃣ Reactive Energy Management
↳ You respond to every demand.
↳ Your peak hours get hijacked.
↳ Your best work never happens.

Solution
↳ Guard your peak hours like high-value meetings
↳ Set response windows, not constant availability

5️⃣ The Consistency Killer
↳ You chase intensity over consistency.
↳ Your systems break under stress.
↳ Your results stay unpredictable.

Solution
↳ Choose one key habit and protect it daily
↳ Track weekly progress, not daily perfection

6️⃣ Hidden Energy Leaks
↳ Unresolved decisions drain you.
↳ Small uncertainties compound.
↳ Your potential slowly fades.

Solution
↳ Make quick decisions on small things fast
↳ Clear lingering tasks in 25-minute sprints

7️⃣ The Recovery Deficit
↳ You wear exhaustion like a badge.
↳ Your edge gets dulled by fatigue.
↳ Your competitors outpace you.

Solution
↳ Schedule rest like it's your most important meeting
↳ Create clear work boundaries every day

What performance killer resonated most? 

️ Repost if you found this insightful.
And followfor more!

postsData.content:
Extraordinary Leadership comes from fullness, ease & flow.

Here is how you can embrace it too.



There is something powerful about the ocean.

Watching the waves, feeling the sun’s warmth, being present there reminded me of this:

Our natural state isn’t lack, force or control
but it is abundance, trust, ease & flow.️

And from this state, extraordinary leadership emerges.

Too often I see leaders, unintentionally block this natural state by:

️ Attaching to outcomes & expectations
️ Pushing for results, leading from fear
️ Trying to control situations
️ Judging or doubting (self or others)
️ Proving self worth

By doing so, they block lasting impact & exponential growth.


This week, I invite you to experience the power of leading from fullness, ease & flow:

️ Start day intentionally
↳Take a deep breath, ground yourself, and set an intention for the day

 Focus on aligned action
↳Lead from vision and purpose, not pressure.
↳Take actions that feel aligned & energizing.

Let go of resistance
↳ When challenges arise, see them as gifts, not roadblocks.
↳ Ask: What is this teaching me?
What do I need to embrace more of?

️ Open yourself to receive
↳ Allow new insights, unexpected opportunities, new ideas to come naturally
↳ Open yourself to be supported.

 Embrace gratitude
↳ Appreciate others and self - your strength, resilience, impact you already make
↳ Be grateful for experiences & what's coming

️ Create moments to connect with self
↳ Pause during the day to check in with yourself.
↳ How do you feel? What do you need?
↳ Are you leading from force or trust?


Which of these will you try this week to embrace leading from state of fullness, ease & flow?

Grateful for the gifts of presence - beauty, ease, and abundance of this magical place. 

 Location: Sapelo, Georgia, USA.

postsData.name:
Mahmoud Owies
Mahmoud Owies
postsData.content:
You don't need to be the best to be confident...

You don't need to be the best to be worthy...

And you definitely don't need to be the best to try...

I've spent most of my life thinking the exact opposite...If I'm not the best at "A" then I don't deserve to get "B".

Why would I win? Why would I be the lucky one?

They're better so it makes sense they'll be the winners...

Essentially, I thought that there's some sort of ranking, and because I'm not the absolute best at everything in life, I don't deserve or I'm not worthy enough to get what I want...

The "aim low because that's what you deserve" mentality....

But no surprise here, I was wrong...Very wrong...

And the thing that made me most wrong is my definition of confidence...

I thought...That confidence means you're better than the rest...

That a confident person is the person who believes they're god's gift to earth and they're the ultimate answer to every problem...

So...Whenever I realized that I'm not the best at something, I immediately shrank and I felt it in my core...I'm not the best...I should hide...Run away...Burry myself...Never try...I don't deserve to...

But confidence is not thinking you're the absolute best at everything...It's not thinking that you're better than others...It's believing that you can figure it out...You can handle whatever life throws at you...Being confident is going for what you want (despite not being the best at the moment) and believing that you can get it...You will get it...You'll figure out a way...You are the master of your own destiny.

How about you? What's your definition of confidence?

P.S. This is the first part (yes, It was a very long post). Stay tuned for the sequel.

postsData.content:
⎈ 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺? 𝗬𝗼𝘂’𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗹𝘀𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗺𝗼𝗼𝗱 ⎈


Ever walked into a room and felt the tension before a word was spoken? Or found yourself irritated, anxious, or frustrated - without really knowing why? Or felt awkward when standing in the group of teenagers?

 𝗘𝗺𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝘀𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱. We pick up the moods of those around us and reflect them back. This happens unconsciously, and before we know it, we’re reacting to feelings that may not even be ours.

At work, this can be powerful or destructive:
-  A leader’s calm can steady a team under pressure.
-  A colleague’s anxiety can make an entire team feel tense.
-  A confident, open mindset can foster trust and collaboration.

Sometimes, we take in emotions that don’t belong to us.
That frustration :
↳ was it really yours, or did you absorb it from a colleague?
That stress :
↳ did it come from your workload, or from your manager?
That cheerfulness :
↳ did someone else made you feel happy?

The more you notice this, the more choice you have in how you respond.

 Leadership is about managing emotional climates. Be intentional about the energy you bring, and mindful of what you take in.

P.S. How do you manage the emotional climate in your team?

postsData.content:
Strong communication saved me $500K in ARR.

Sounds dramatic? Maybe. But it’s true.

A few roles ago, I had to oversee the deprecation of a product used by our smaller customers. We had a new and improved solution ready to go—but with a higher price tag and added complexity that many customers didn’t want (or need).

Cue potential churn panic.

My job? Prevent a mass exodus.

Here’s how strong, proactive communication helped us keep 70% of our customers and over $500K in ARR 

The Playbook:

 Personalized Emails – No generic “we’re sunsetting this product” nonsense. We crafted targeted, transparent messages explaining the why, the what, and the when—plus clear options.

 Webinar with FAQs – We didn’t just announce change; we walked them through it. A live session let customers hear the plan firsthand and get their biggest questions answered.

 1:1 Calls – High-touch for those who needed it. No one felt abandoned in the process.

 Migration & Exit Options – We gave customers choices, not ultimatums. Some migrated, some left (on good terms), and we even helped a few transition to alternative solutions.

 Consistent Updates – No surprises. Regular check-ins gave customers control over the transition.

 Post-Migration Support – Because the customer experience doesn’t stop after the switch. We made sure they were set up for success.

The Outcome?

 500K ARR saved
 ~70% retention
 Stronger customer trust

Here’s the lesson: Communication can be more powerful than the product changes themselves. Customers don’t just need a new tool—they need clarity, support, and a sense of control.

SaaS is always changing. Sometimes all you have is communication. Use it wisely.

postsData.content:
Deep down, I was wondering, 

"Did I make a big mistake?"

I was brand new.
My first project was to completely redo the discipline process in our school, and it really wasn't working out.

Everything I tried wasn't sticking.

I tried flowcharts, coaching, training, and workshops - and nothing was making a difference. I could not get the staff (or students) to follow the systems and procedures.

To say I felt frustrated, or, overwhelmed would be an understatement.

In the first two weeks of school nearly 100 different students were referred to me.

I was paralyzed with self-doubt and the basic feeling that I just wasn't good enough to actually make the change.

Then I had an epiphany.

When I was feeling like I needed to blame someone else for something - that was me relinquishing control. It was me not taking ownership over myself and my role.

My role was to support the staff, not lecture them on how to be better. It was to actually get down in the weeds with them and learn about their challenges. Learn the patterns that they were in - and then guide them through it.

It took me a few tries, but I understand now that those feelings of inadequacy and overwhelm are really just signals that I need to step into my ownership more.

If it means taking a training on a specific skill, or paying a coach to guide me through a challenge - that's on me.

It's always on me.

Within 3 months, the referrals were down to about 10 students per week.

And the crazy thing is, I did it by being calmer, more empathetic, and without burning my staff relationally.

So, if you're...
...feeling overwhelmed
...feeling uncertain
...feeling like you’re failing

Listen to your inner voice and learn from it.

What are you trying to unload? What do you need to take accountability for?

The most accelerated growth you experience comes when you go and do those things that you're trying to avoid.

What struggle are you learning from today?

--

This is exciting for me to share!
For six months, I dug into the Tao Te Ching, and it helped me clarify the changes that every CEO, COO, and entrepreneur NEEDS to make to lead without effort.

So I wrote a 4-part, 15 lesson guide.
No fluff and no hacks.

Go check out my featured section for the FREE download!

I've noticed people who believe using abusive language makes them appear cool. 

They try hard to fit in with their friend circle, where they feel pressured to use bad words, smoke, drink, and mock other genders just to be accepted.

If you're compromising your values to befriend these people, remember that they're not truly your friends. Friendship shouldn't force you to completely change your personality or adopt bad habits.

In today's digital age, it's easy to consume content that we enjoy. When we see a video with a large number of views, it can be tempting to click and watch.

However, just because a video is popular doesn't mean we should mindlessly consume its content.

Just as we take care of our physical health by eating nutritious food, we should also prioritize our mental health by consuming good content.

Insulting others, mocking our parents, partners, and friends, and using abusive language are not ways to appear cool.

I hope you understand my message and are mindful of what you consume. It's easy to blame others for their actions, but it's our responsibility to take care of our own mental health.

postsData.content:
The #1 Money Habit That Can Transform Finances

Many people believe that building wealth is about earning more money. But the real game-changer isn’t just income... it’s how money is managed. One simple habit can make all the difference:

Track Every Rupee Spent

This small shift brings clarity, control, and better financial decisions. Here’s how this small habit leads to massive results:

 Awareness Leads to Smarter Spending

Most people underestimate how much they spend on small, unnecessary expenses. Tracking expenses helps identify wasteful spending and redirect money toward meaningful goals.

 Saves Before Spending, Not After

A common mistake is spending first and saving what’s left. Instead, setting aside savings before spending ensures financial security and long-term growth.

 Prevents Lifestyle Creep

As income grows, so do expenses; unless spending is monitored. Tracking expenses helps maintain discipline, ensuring that a higher income leads to more wealth, not just higher bills.

 Makes Budgeting Easy

A clear record of spending makes it simple to set a realistic budget. It helps allocate funds efficiently, balancing necessities, savings, and enjoyment.

How to Start Toda

1️⃣ Use an App or Notebook
Track every expense, no matter how small.

2️⃣ Review Weekly
Identify areas to cut back or optimize.

3️⃣ Set Spending Limits
Create categories and stick to a budget.

4️⃣ Automate Savings
Transfer a portion of income to savings before spending.

"Take the 30-Day Challenge"

For one month, track every expense. The insights gained can lead to better financial decisions and long-term wealth.

Have you ever tracked your spending? What did you learn? Share your experience in the comments.

postsData.content:
Last week, I spoke with a VP Sales at a $25M ARR company about RFPs. We both agreed: We should stop wasting our time.

I’ve participated in so many RFPs, but lately, I don’t want to participate in any.

I had this same feeling in my previous Head of Sales role selling into Banks & Government.

And I feel it again now as a cross-functional revenue leader selling into several industries.

Why?

Because my teams have wasted months of execution power filling out RFPs—only to realize we had no real shot at winning.

RFPs are a trap for most sellers.

Here’s the harsh truth about RFPs:

• You’re late to the party. If you weren’t engaged before the RFP dropped, you’re just filling a procurement requirement.
• The customer already has a vendor in mind. Most RFPs aren’t an “open competition”—they’re a validation exercise to justify a decision that’s already been made.
• You’re wasting weeks (or months) on a lost cause. The opportunity cost is massive: instead of chasing an unwinnable RFP, you could be closing real deals.

The best sellers know when to walk away.

When to Walk Away From an RFP
• No equal playing field—another vendor shaped the RFP.
• No internal criteria process to validate RFP feasibility.
• Vague, inconsistent RFP documentation.
• Decision criteria & timelines are unclear.

If you check any of these, walk away.

When to Consider Competing
• You’ve built champions and have executive buy-in.
• You’ve identified clear differentiators tied to customer priorities.
• You helped shape the RFP or had meaningful conversations beforehand.

Even though I’m not a fan, buyers still buy through RFPs.

If you can validate feasibility, go for it. Otherwise, withdraw.

5 RFP Strategies from GTM Experts in my Notion library:

1. Multithread & Stay Connected to the Executive
"I stayed close to an SVP via text during an RFP. It gave me inside access to influence the process—even when procurement tried to shut it down."

2. Turn the RFP Against Your Competition
"We asked key questions in front of the buying team to highlight our differentiators. Our competitor realized they couldn’t compete—and quit."

3. Help the Buyer Write the RFP
"The best way to win an RFP? Write it yourself. We did this for 2 out of 3 of our biggest RFP wins."

4. Challenge the Process
"If procurement shuts you down, you’re pushing the right way. If they kick you out, you were never going to win anyway."

5. Make Competitors Tap Out
"We structured our Q&A session to highlight our key differentiators. Our competitor couldn’t keep up and withdrew from the process entirely."

The best sellers know when to say no.

RFPs inflate pipelines, drain team morale, and pull resources from real, winnable deals.

Unless you’ve influenced the process, the dice are loaded against you.

Time is your most valuable asset.

Use it wisely.

What’s your take on RFPs?

PS. Today, In my newsletter , I will break down how experts run RFPs. Consider subscribing to improve your RFP process.

Our rivers, lakes, and oceans are drowning in pollution. From plastic waste to industrial runoff, water pollution threatens ecosystems, wildlife, and ultimately, human health.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗻𝗲𝘄𝘀:
We already have a wealth of technological solutions to combat it - advanced filtration systems, AI-driven monitoring, biodegradable materials, and innovative waste management strategies. Science and engineering have provided us with powerful tools to clean our waters.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗮𝗱 𝗻𝗲𝘄𝘀:
Yet, despite all these advancements, pollution persists. Why?
Because technology alone cannot solve a problem rooted in human behavior. Real change begins with a shift in mindset. We must rethink our relationship with nature, embrace responsibility, and act with greater awareness.
Without a cultural and behavioral transformation, even the most sophisticated solutions will only be a temporary fix. If we truly want to protect our waters, we need to change not just our methods, but our mindset.

Super Bowl Leadership: Game-Changing Strategies for Business Success
Champions Aren’t Born—They’re Built

Last night, the Philadelphia Eagles returned to the Super Bowl, seeking redemption after their loss to the Kansas City Chiefs two years ago. Throughout the season, both teams demonstrated unwavering determination to reach the championship game. Despite a challenging journey, they succeeded. Although the Chiefs were favored to win, the Eagles had other plans.

How does the big game mirror the business world? Being an underdog doesn't equate to being out of the game. The lessons we learn from winning teams can be invaluable in business.

Winning the Super Bowl isn’t solely about talent—it encompasses strategy, execution, and an unshakable mindset. The same holds true in business. Whether you're leading a startup or an established company, the landscape is ever-changing:

Market conditions shift.
Competitors evolve.
New challenges emerge.

Once the game begins, prior circumstances become irrelevant. Success hinges on preparation, leadership, and the ability to adapt under pressure. In business, you might be entering a competitive market or guiding a team through uncertainty. Regardless of expectations, the key is to:

Remain humble.
Prioritize your team.
Execute with precision.

The best leaders, like the best teams, don’t just show up—they play to win. Here’s how you can apply Super Bowl-level leadership to build a business that thrives under any conditions.

In our latest blog, I explore several parallels between championship sports teams and successful businesses.

This was what I was sending when I first got on LI 5 years ago

So here's what I do now to book calls consistently on LinkedIn using cold DMs

And that's it

I wish it was more complicated

That way I could make money selling the secret sauce

Maybe I'll add an extra 30 unnecessary steps and sell a course for $5997 called "LinkedIn DM Mastery for the severely socially inept"

postsData.content:
You don’t need a certain number of friends, just a number of friends you can be certain of. 

Isn’t it funny that for a lot of adults, that popularity-contest-high-school mentality never goes away? Some people tend to think that the number of friends you have correlates to your status. More friends = more popular.

Friends, that wasn’t true in high school and it’s definitely not true in adulthood. Let’s break down a couple myths about that belief.

First, popularity and status are absolutely not real. Think back to the popular crowd in high school. Did everyone like them? Probably not. Were they more respected than everyone else? Again, that’s unlikely. It was just a group of people that felt like they had more clout than everyone else. Popularity is such a subjective thing, it should never be the end goal we’re striving for.

Second, quality over quantity has never been more true than in regards to friendship. It might feel great to have 20 people you can go clubbing with, but that’s pretty meaningless if you don’t have a single person you can talk to about your struggles or life goals.

Here’s my advice for you. Spend your time and energy building a few meaningful friendships with a small circle of people. I’m not saying that you can’t build friendly relationships with a large number of people- because, seriously, what would LinkedIn be without the chance to get to know so many amazing people?! What I am saying is that you need to make sure you have a few close friends that are your go-to people, the ones who are happy to be your emergency contact or go-to phone call when you’ve had a terrible day at work.

Build a small community of friends who are always there for each other, and I promise, it will change your life.

A small circle of TRUE friends is better any day than the choas of a crowd! “A real friend is one who walks in when the rest of the world walks out.” We need to treasure these friendships! Much love always! ️
Marsha Belote isn’t this the gospel truth?

Are you ready for the agentic revolution in automation?

As I delve deeper into discussions with various providers, a clear pattern emerges: agentic capabilities are becoming the cornerstone of all digital automation.

postsData.name:
Stacie Sussman
Stacie Sussman
postsData.content:
We’re always chasing 
the next milestone, 
the next goal, 
the next version of success.

And that’s a really good thing.

Being surrounded by ambitious
people who push forward
is what fuels growth.

And we’re all in on that!

But here’s what we
don’t do often enough,
look back.

—> Look back at where
we started.

—> Look back at the challenges
we overcame.

—> Look back at the moments
we thought we wouldn’t make it,
but did.

Growth of course is reaching
the next level.

But it’s also about recognizing
how many levels we’ve
already climbed.

Just look at the Philadelphia Eagles.

After losing to the Kansas City Chiefs
in the Super Bowl two years ago,
they fought their way back and
secured a 40-22 win.

They didn’t just redeem themselves,
they proved their resilience,
learned from their losses,
and came back stronger.

So today, take a second.

Look ahead at where you’re going.

Then turn around and appreciate
just how far you’ve come.

Because that progress?

That resilience?

That’s the real win.

comments.commentText: Such a powerful reminder to celebrate our journeys and the lessons learned along the way.

Comparing ourselves is oftentimes a trap for being not-so-nice to ourselves... except when we compare ourselves today to our previous selves. 

I've trained my mind to reflect this way and it feels great to think of my own progress... and it's also fuel to keep going!

postsData.commentAdded: What an inspiring perspective! Celebrating our journey and resilience fuels future success. Here’s to recognizing every step weve taken! 🌟
